title: Five Days / Paid to Kill (1954, Film-Noir) by Montgomery Tully | Colorized Movie

sources.title: Five Days / Paid to Kill (1954, Film-Noir) by Montgomery Tully | Colorized Movie
sources.description:
Death Before Debt!?
A failed business deal forces James Nevill to blackmail his weak-willed friend into murdering him so that his wife can collect his life insurance, but circumstances suddenly change, and not for the better...

Original title: Five Days (1954) AKA: Paid to Kill 
This film is subtitled in many languages.

Black & White version: https://youtu.be/fhdPo-4gLhs


Director: Montgomery Tully
Writer: Paul Tabori
Stars: Dane Clark, Cecile Chevreau, Paul Carpenter
Genres:  Colorized, Crime, Drama, Film-Noir, Mystery, Thriller


00:00 Full Movie (with subtitles)
01:35 A conversation between characters regarding a business deal and a pending decision.
06:03 A dramatic turn of events unfolds as a business rivalry intensifies, leading to personal sacrifices and hidden agendas.
12:20 A man is pressured to carry out a deadly task for money, leading to a tense confrontation.
15:54 A suspenseful conversation unfolds between two characters discussing a plan involving deceit and potential harm.
20:58 A suspenseful film revolving around a murder case and a web of deceit and betrayal.
27:10 In a corporate setting, a young chairman's potential mistake is discussed at a party, leading to a meeting with a new associate.
31:13 A series of events unfold as characters discuss business matters and personal relationships.
34:47 Betrayal, deception, and urgency unfold in a noir film as characters navigate through dangerous situations.
42:38 Mystery unfolds as characters search for Paul Kirby, encountering deception and danger.
48:35 Investigation into a bombing incident leads to intense interrogations and suspicions among the characters.
53:52 Secret dealings and suspicions arise as characters navigate a complex web of deceit and danger.
58:48 A twisted plot unfolds as characters navigate through deceit and danger.
1:05:33 A dramatic confrontation leads to a plea for mercy and a potential tragedy.
